DOCNAME: CASE OF RINGIER AXEL SPRINGER SLOVAKIA, A.S. v. SLOVAKIA
JUDGES: Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ineta Ziemele;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant company was established in DATE and has its seat in GPE . It is a multimedia publishing house .
CARDINAL . The applicant company ’s legal predecessor , ORG , was the publisher of a popular national DATE newspaper .
CARDINAL . A. employed , among others , reporters PERSON and C.

CARDINAL . On DATE B. received an anonymous phone call informing him of an incident taking place at that very moment involving individuals NORP and PERSON The incident was said to be taking place in a public restaurant and is described below .
CARDINAL . At that time , NORP was a Member of ORG , a municipal mayor and the president of a political party . PERSON , for his part , was vice - president of ORG .
CARDINAL . In DATE that followed , A. and another publisher printed a series of articles about the incident . The details are described in DATE below .

CARDINAL . The behaviour of PERSON in the context of the incident was subsequently investigated by ORG , in particular as regards the allegations that he had wet his pants and threatened to organise civic disturbances ( see below ) .
On the basis of a report issued on DATE , PERSON , the personnel of the restaurant and a number of witnesses having been interviewed , no impropriety on the part of PERSON was established .
CARDINAL . At a later point PERSON left the police force on his own initiative .

CARDINAL . Both NORP and PERSON subsequently successfully sued PERSON for libel . The proceedings concerned by the present application are those instituted by E. They are described in paragraphs CARDINAL to CARDINAL below .
CARDINAL . Following the proceedings , in DATE , PERSON was merged with the applicant company .

CARDINAL . In the anonymous phone call mentioned in paragraph CARDINAL above , the caller informed PERSON that NORP and PERSON were sitting in a public restaurant and that NORP had previously urinated on the terrace of that restaurant .

CARDINAL . In a matter of minutes , PERSON arrived at the restaurant , where he saw NORP and PERSON as they were about to leave . He ordered a drink and observed them . Judging by the way they were walking and holding each other up , PERSON had the impression that they were under the influence . In total , PERSON had spent TIME in the restaurant before NORP and PERSON left .
CARDINAL . B. then interviewed the waitress and some of the diners , following which he left and wrote the first of the articles described below .
CARDINAL . The following morning PERSON revisited the restaurant , re - interviewed the waitress and photographed the location of the incident .
CARDINAL . In DATE contact and a meeting were arranged between F. , an eyewitness to the incident , and PERSON , who was assisted by ORG and another colleague .

CARDINAL . Contact and a meeting between PERSON and PERSON were also arranged with a view to obtaining PERSON ’s position . In that meeting , PERSON admitted having been at the restaurant with NORP but denied any impropriety . He requested that his name not be disclosed , as that would ruin his career in the police force .
CARDINAL . On DATE the paper in question printed an article entitled “ [ NORP ] ‘ introduced himself’ in [ the restaurant ] on DATE ” . The article included the following text :

“ ‘ [ NORP ] is sitting in [ the restaurant ] rollicking drunk’ , CARDINAL of our readers reported to the editorial office [ of the newspaper ] on DATE TIME . As we checked with our own eyes , it really was true . The president [ of the political party ] was really sitting in the restaurant named and his appearance revealed that our reader had not done him an injustice . [ D. ] was accompanied by an individual who claimed to be a high - ranking police official . ‘ Gentlemen brothers’ ( páni bratia ) [ D. ] boomed as he staggered from the terrace to the bar . Then , as if he wanted to take flight with his arms outstretched , [ he ] gave an order for departure and headed for the stairs . His friend even offered to help him out , but [ D. ] refused . ‘ Come with GPE [ he ] called out to the DATE or so diners present . Where , he did not say . But none of the diners stood up . As alleged by several eyewitnesses , only shortly before our arrival [ NORP ] had urinated off the terrace of the restaurant onto the pavement . According to our findings the president [ of the members of the party ] arrived at the restaurant [ ... ] already in an inebriated state : ‘ when he arrived he already looked a state ; he only had a few cognacs PERSON , we were told by CARDINAL of those present , who does not wish to be named . Contented , [ NORP ] was finally driven off [ in his car ] by his driver , who had been hanging about outside nervously the entire time waiting for the president to have his fill of fun ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the paper printed an article entitled “ Have the leader and high - ranking police officer planned a coup ? An eyewitness to [ NORP ] ’s running wild has spoken out ” . The article included the following text :

“ [ The paper ] was the first to report that DATE the president of [ the political party ] [ NORP ] , while intoxicated , urinated off the terrace of a GPE restaurant [ ... ] onto the pavement . For publishing this information , [ NORP ] wants to sue our paper and claim CARDINAL [ NORP korunas ] . We bring you now the account of an eyewitness to [ D. ’s ] running wild on DATE : ‘ I was sitting with my friends at the bar . [ NORP ] arrived with a man who claimed to be a high - ranking police officer . [ NORP ] came up to the bar , obviously under the influence , ordered CARDINAL beers and [ the CARDINAL ] went to sit on the terrace . [ ... ] On the terrace , they were served by a waitress . They were drinking cognac . After a while CARDINAL man who had been sitting with them left and said that the policemen had wet [ himself ] on the chair . The policeman himself then walked from the terrace to the interior of the restaurant and we really saw that he was completely wasted . He came back TIME and fell asleep in his ORG . The witness added , ‘ the policeman also told [ NORP ] : ‘ I will ensure that there are civic disturbances within DATE , do n’t worry about anything , but you have to provide me with support’ . [ D. ] rejoined : ‘ Do n’t worry , you are under my protection.’ We laughed at that because [ NORP ] must have misunderstood the meaning of support , since he started urinating off the terrace . [ He ] and the policeman were holding each other up . The concrete railing is relatively high , so he had difficulty , he was standing on tip toes , he was doing what he could’ , the [ witness ] recalls as [ NORP ] answered the call of nature . [ ... ] [ The witness ] also recalls that the policeman ’s head had dropped and had had to be supported by a plastic chair [ ... ] . [ The paper ] has found out that [ NORP ] was in fact in the company of a high - ranking police officer . His identity is known to our paper . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the paper printed an article entitled “ [ The Minister of the Interior ] has entrusted the investigation of the scandal to ORG . [ NORP ] went on the rampage with the police vicepresident ” . The article included the following text :

“ [ The paper ] has established the identity of the high - ranking police officer who accompanied the leader of [ the political party ] [ NORP ] to the restaurant DATE [ ... ] . [ D. ] went on the rampage in this establishment with the vice - president of the police [ corps ] , colonel [ E. ] . Shortly after the incident the president of the [ political party ] declined to disclose the identity of the man , identifying him in the media as a friend . The Minister of the Interior [ ... ] has already charged ORG with investigating the scandal . ‘ I can not believe things went that far . If they did , then I will act according to the findings of the investigation . Everyone is the master of their own ORG the Minister stated for the paper . He did so in reply to our question as to whether the vicepresident would be removed from office should the information that we had been published in our DATE be confirmed . Let us be reminded that , according to an eyewitness to the incident , the president of [ the political party ] and the vicepresident of the police [ corps ] were drinking cognac on a terrace . ‘ After a while CARDINAL man who had been sitting with them left and said that the policeman had wet [ himself ] on a chair . The policeman himself then walked from the terrace to the interior of the restaurant and we really saw that he was completely wasted’ , the witness recalled . According to him , the vice - president [ E. ] also held [ NORP ] up when the latter , standing on tip toes , urinated off the terrace onto the pavement . The witness likewise heard [ E. ] suggest to [ NORP ] that within DATE he would ensure that there were civic disturbances . [ He ] asked the president of [ the political party ] for ‘ support’ . [ E. ] confirmed to the paper DATE that he had been drinking in [ the restaurant ] with [ NORP ] . However , he refutes the claim that he had wet [ himself ] . He also claims that he has never planned any civic disturbances with [ NORP ] . The president of the police stated for the paper that : ‘ If it were proven that what you have written is true , I , as president [ of the police corps ] , would be very sorry . That ’s all I have to say.’ ”
CARDINAL . The articles mentioned above were also published in the on - line version of the newspaper on CARDINAL , DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . Some of the information from the articles mentioned above was used in an article published on DATE in a newspaper in GPE entitled : “ [ NORP ] did not urinate onto the people alone , he was assisted by the vicepresident of the police force ” .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON civil courts for libel , demanding publication of a correction and an apology and claiming the equivalent of QUANTITY ( ORG ) in compensation for damage to his reputation .

CARDINAL . E. admitted having been at the restaurant and having consumed alcoholic beverages in a moderate quantity with NORP at the given time but contested the truthfulness of all the other facts alleged in the articles . He argued that his personal integrity had been interfered with and that he had been falsely discredited , in particular in the sphere of his service ranking , his civic dignity and his family life .

CARDINAL . On DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE ORG Okresný súd ) held hearings . At the latter hearing , ORG invited the parties to adduce further evidence and instructed them that once the evidence - taking was closed , they would have only a limited possibly to adduce further evidence in the event of an appeal . The parties declared that they had no further evidence to adduce , following which the evidencetaking was closed and a judgment was given .

CARDINAL . In the judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG found for the claimant . It ordered A. to publish in the abovementioned newspaper an article correcting the inaccurate information , accepting that such information was false and apologising to E.
A. was also ordered to pay the amount claimed ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) together with the claimant ’s legal costs .
CARDINAL . ORG had examined testimonies by NORP , his driver PERSON , the claimant ’s wife , PERSON , C. , F. , another diner at the restaurant , PERSON , and CARDINAL other witnesses .
CARDINAL . ORG had also examined the contents of the court file concerning the libel action by NORP on the basis of the same facts and the case file concerning disciplinary proceedings against E.
Reports by ORG and a sworn expert on toxicology had also been taken into account .

CARDINAL . ORG considered untrustworthy the submissions of PERSON and C. , the authors of the articles , CARDINAL of whom had witnessed a part of the reported incident , and PERSON , on whose statements PERSON and C. had mostly relied .
CARDINAL . ORG considered that NORP , PERSON and the remaining witnesses either did not confirm or actually contested the reported facts as to the behaviour of NORP and PERSON
CARDINAL . In conclusion , ORG had failed to establish the truthfulness of the facts and the articles could not be considered a justified critique .
CARDINAL . ORG observed that there were opposing interests at stake , in particular , the freedom of expression under LAW and the right to respect for private life under LAW .

CARDINAL . Weighing the right of PERSON to have his personal integrity protected against the right of A. to freedom of expression , ORG found that the articles had significantly , and without acceptable justification , damaged PERSON ’s position in his employment , family and society in general .

CARDINAL . A. appealed , arguing that ORG had erred in the assessment of the facts and in the application of the law . In particular , ORG had failed to explain why it considered untrustworthy the evidence of B. , C. and F. It also contended that ORG had arbitrarily considered PERSON , who had had no clear recollection of the relevant events , to be the key witness for the defence , while the key witness had in fact been PERSON , who confirmed that PERSON had been intoxicated , that he had spoken of receiving protection [ from NORP ] , that PERSON ’s head had dropped and had to be supported by a plastic chair and that PERSON had had a damp patch on his trousers , giving the impression that he had urinated in them .
A. requested that the discrepancy in the testimonies be explained by means of a face - to - face witness meeting .

CARDINAL . ORG ( Krajský súd ) called a hearing of the appeal for DATE . A. was summoned through the intermediary of its lawyer but excused itself and agreed to the hearing ’s taking place in its absence .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG held a hearing at which it questioned the claimant ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . Neither A. nor its lawyer was present .
CARDINAL . Following the hearing , on DATE , ORG upheld the first - instance judgment but reduced the amount of damages to the equivalent of some EUR CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . ORG found that neither B. nor C. nor F. had seen or directly testified that PERSON had urinated in his trousers , that he had incited civic disturbances and that he had held NORP up while the latter had urinated from the terrace of the restaurant .

CARDINAL . ORG relied on the principle of “ truthfulness of information ” , consisting of the following elements . Information intended for publication was to be verified by CARDINAL but ideally more credible and mutually independent sources with care adequate to the circumstances . The law could only protect the journalists if they could establish the truthfulness of the impugned material as well as their bona fides in publishing it and the presence of a public interest in the matter .

CARDINAL . Under the applicable procedural rules it was not permissible at the appellate stage to take new evidence , at the request of the parties , which had not been adduced at the first - instance level . ORG found that it therefore could not call a face - to - face witness meeting as requested by A. It followed that , in the given evidentiary situation , the conclusions of the first - instance court as to the essence of the claim were justified .

CARDINAL . However , ORG considered the existing evidence insufficient to justify the award of damages made by the first - instance court . It was therefore necessary to take new evidence of the court ’s own motion by hearing the claimant and , eventually , to reduce the amount of the award . It held it established that the greatest loss that the claimant had suffered had been in the area of his employment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant company lodged a complaint under LAW with ORG ( Ústavný súd ) , directed against the decision of ORG .

CARDINAL . The applicant company pointed out that ORG had considered as decisive whether or not the defendant could establish the truthfulness of the reported facts . This was , however , not compatible with the principle of freedom of expression , which also extended to untrue information .

CARDINAL . The applicant company submitted that PERSON had verified the facts by witnessing the incident in person and that B. and C. had verified the facts by interviewing witness PERSON and the claimant . They had thereby acted bona fides and in accordance with journalistic ethics . What also was of relevance was that the claimant had been a public figure . The ordinary courts , however , had completely omitted to carry out an assessment of these essential components of the concept of freedom of expression .

CARDINAL . The applicant company considered the amount of the damages awarded to be excessive , referring to the judgment of ORG in the case of PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINAL-III ) , where the equivalent of CARDINAL ORG Units worth of damages in a libel case had been considered excessive .

CARDINAL . The applicant company contended that it had been incompatible with the guarantees of a fair trial and , in particular , the equality of arms principle for ORG to base its ruling on damages solely on the additional evidence provided by the claimant , as this evidence had not been adduced by the parties , it had served CARDINAL of the parties and – as it had been taken at the appellate level – the defendant had had no opportunity to contest it . Moreover , this evidence was not impartial by definition and ORG had failed to corroborate it by other evidence , which was contrary to the established judicial practice .

CARDINAL . As regards the finding that the claimant ’s greatest loss had been in the sphere of his employment , ORG had failed to take into account that the disciplinary proceedings against the claimant had in fact ended in his favour .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant company , the ordinary courts had erred in the assessment of the witness evidence , in particular that provided by PERSON , by arbitrarily selecting elements benefiting the claimant . In so far as the testimony of PERSON was concerned , in addition , the ordinary courts had failed to support their findings with adequate reasoning .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible . Observing that it was not a court of a third or fourth instance , ORG found no indication of any unlawfulness or constitutionally relevant arbitrariness in the proceedings and decisions of ORG . As to the complainant ’s specific argument that ORG had taken new evidence ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) without informing the complainant and giving it an opportunity to comment , ORG found that the complainant had failed to exhaust ordinary remedies by raising this argument by way of an appeal on points of law under LAW ( f ) of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL Coll . , as amended – “ the ORG ” ) .
The decision of ORG was served on the applicant company on DATE .
CARDINAL . The status of international human rights treaties in GPE is defined in LAW , the relevant part of which reads as follows :
“ International treaties on human rights and fundamental freedoms .... which have been ratified and promulgated in the manner required by statute take precedence over statue . ”
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that :

“ In the discharge of their function , judges are independent and , in decision - making , they are only bound by the LAW , constitutional law , international treaties under LAW [ of LAW ] and statute . ”
CARDINAL . The protection of personal integrity is governed by the provisions of Articles CARDINAL et seq . In so far as relevant , these provide :
Every natural person shall have the right to protection of his or her personal integrity , in particular his or her ... civil honour and human dignity , as well as privacy , name ...

CARDINAL . Every natural person shall have the right , inter alia , to request an order restraining any unjustified interference with his or her personal integrity , an order cancelling out the effects of such interference and an award of appropriate compensation .

CARDINAL . NORP If the satisfaction afforded under paragraph CARDINAL of this LAW is insufficient , in particular because the injured party ’s dignity or social standing has been considerably diminished , the injured party shall also be entitled to financial compensation for nonpecuniary damage .

CARDINAL . When determining the amount of compensation payable under paragraph CARDINAL of this LAW , the court shall take into account the seriousness of the harm suffered by the injured party and the circumstances in which the violation of his or her rights occurred . ”

CARDINAL . The Code regulates the conduct of the court and parties in civil proceedings so as to ensure the just protection of the rights and legally recognised interests of the parties as well as promoting the observance of laws , honest fulfilment of duties and respect for the rights of other persons ( LAW .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL it provides that parties to civil proceedings have equal standing . The court is duty - bound to ensure they have equal opportunity to assert their rights .
CARDINAL . NORP Parties to the proceedings have the right to comment on any evidence adduced and taken ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under LAW ( d ) , civil proceedings can be reopened where the ORG has found a violation of the requesting party ’s Convention rights and where serious consequences of the violation have not been adequately redressed by the award of just satisfaction .
CARDINAL . A Court of Appeal can in principle reassess evidence or take further evidence provided that it can be done without delay ( LAW , as in force at the relevant time ) .
CARDINAL . Under LAW an appeal on points of law ( dovolanie ) lies against final and binding decisions of appellate courts if certain statutory admissibility criteria are met .
CARDINAL . The general admissibility criteria , that is , those applicable to both judgments ( rozsudok ) and resolutions ( uznesenie ) , are set out in Article CARDINAL .

These comprise situations where : ( a ) the courts decided in a matter outside their jurisdiction ; ( b ) a person who acted as a party to the proceedings lacked the legal capacity to be a party to court proceedings ; ( c ) a party to the proceedings lacked the capacity to act in court proceedings and was not duly represented ; ( d ) the courts decided on a matter which had been res iudicata or which had already been pending in other proceedings ( lis pendens ) ; ( e ) the proceedings could only commence by way of an action and no such action was actually filed ; ( f ) the courts prevented a party to the proceedings from acting before them ; and ( g ) where the case was decided upon by an excluded judge or where the composition of the court was incorrect .
CARDINAL . In addition to the above - mentioned general admissibility criteria , special admissibility criteria apply if ORG decided in the form of a judgment . These are defined in LAW .
CARDINAL . Under paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL an appeal on points of law is admissible where the appellate court overturned the judgment of a firstinstance court .

CARDINAL . In accordance with paragraph CARDINAL of Article CARDINAL , an appeal on points of law also lies against a judgment of the appellate court in which the latter did not follow the binding legal view previously expressed in the same matter by the court of cassation .

CARDINAL . Under LAW ( a ) , an appeal on points of law is also admissible against a judgment of an appellate court in which it upholds a judgment of a first - instance court and , at the same time , rules that such an appeal is admissible as the case concerns a matter of particular legal importance .

CARDINAL . Finally , under LAW ( b ) , an appeal on points of law is also admissible against a second judgment of an appellate court in which it upholds a second judgment of a first - instance court if , in the second round , the first - instance court decided differently than in its first judgment ( which had been quashed by the first decision of ORG ) because it was bound by the legal view expressed by ORG in its first judgment . This rule also applies to the third and , as the case may be , subsequent judgments of ORG .

DATE . As to the merits , an appeal on points of law can only be based on the grounds defined in LAW , that is to say that the proceedings have been vitiated by an error envisaged in LAW ( letter ( a ) ) , that the proceedings have been vitiated by another error that resulted in an incorrect decision on the merits ( letter ( b ) ) and that the decision rests on an error of law ( letter ( c ) ) .

CARDINAL . In a decision of DATE in an unrelated case no . PERSON . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL , ORG observed that , in relation to evidence - taking , the right to a fair hearing LAW CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Convention was to be understood so that a party to the proceedings must be provided with the opportunity to take part in the evidence - taking in a manner defined by statute , which means to adduce evidence , to be present when the evidence is being taken , including the right to interview witnesses and parties , and to take a position in respect of evidence adduced and taken . For that reason a party to the proceedings must always have the opportunity to be present at the evidence - taking . Should that not have been the case , the error can be qualified as “ judicial conduct that has prevented the party from acting before a court ” , thereby constituting a ground for admissibility of an appeal on points of law under LAW ( f ) of the ORG .
